headline: Cast Iron Cornbread
description: Chef John's cast iron cornbread recipe is very inexpensive to make, but that'll be the last thing anyone will be thinking about as they eat it!
name: Cast Iron Cornbread

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
Melt butter in a cast iron skillet. Turn off the heat; set the skillet aside.

Whisk buttermilk, cornmeal, eggs, honey, salt, and cayenne pepper together in a large bowl. Add flour and 1/2 of the butter from the pan; whisk again. Pour batter over remaining butter in the skillet.
Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, about 25 minutes. Let cool briefly before slicing.

review.reviewBody: I omitted the pepper added 4 tablespoons sugar and 1 tbls honey, no buttermilk so i added 1 tbls white vinegar to room temp milk and 4 teaspoons baking power to the flower. I used 2tbls butter in the pan and 4 in the mix also added 1 can sweet cream corn. the mix looked a little loose but rose to a beautiful bread took 5 min longer in oven at 425

I followed two of the suggestions in the chef's notes-- adding baking soda and salt to all-purpose flour (I didn't have self-rising) and also cutting the butter-- and 6 TBS was more than enough. The cup + one half of buttermilk makes a very moist cornbread. I have another recipe that was similar but used 2/3 cup sugar VS 3 TBS honey that this recipe calls for-- my family preferred this recipe hands down. The balance of ingredients is perfect.
I use grease the skillet with Crisco and put in the oven when I turn it on.

I love Chef John recipes but I'm definitely struggling with this one. I have tried it twice now, and will continue modifying. I tend to not like things too sweet but with this recipe I would say to add extra honey and if possible, some chopped up canned sweet corn, maybe 1-2 tablespoons. Additionally, I have had better luck reducing the flour by 1/3 cup and adding 1/3 more cornmeal to help it taste less flourish. Chef John says to put leave half the melted butter in the skillet but I would say add most of it back in to the cornbread so you don't get that browning and burning around the edges.
This was perfect. Exactly what I was looking for - thank you!

Too dense, add baking soda.
Too much butter. Literally floating in it. Put it all in the batter with a thin costing in the pan.

I followed Chef John's recipe exactly, and paid attention to his tips -- reducing butter to 6 T total. It looked beautiful and had a gorgeous crumb. I was generous in my shake of Cayenne -- it wasn't spicy at all. I also added cooked fresh corn off the cob. Next time I'll add one more T of honey.
Great and easy. Substituted whole milk for buttermilk. It seems to have worked. Made it on the BBQ at the cottage in a cast iron pan. Lid thermometer reading 375.

This is a super easy and fun recipe for basic cornbread. The consistency is near-perfect, with a moist center and a crunchy “crust”. I used a store-brand wildflower honey and two pinches of cayenne, though I couldn’t taste any spice in the finished product. It is a little bland on its own and needs a little bit of condiment or to be served as a side for chili or bbq. I just had a piece with some honey drizzled on top along with a piece with a little fig jam, and both were tasty. If I make this again, I might try adding jalapeños to the batter.
I liked this recipe and it turned out well. I did add a little less than 1/4 cup of sugar since we like a little sweeter cornbread.
Sorry but this was the worst cornbread recipe I’ve ever tried. Absolutely flavorless and I followed the recipe exactly. Too bad. It would have been nice to go along with my pot of chili

Hands down the best cornbread I have ever eaten. I live in Texas, I have eaten lots of cornbread. Even better than my Momma’s!! Shhh, don’t tell her! It baked up beautifully and tasted amazing. I don’t like sweet cornbread, this was perfect!!

I have made this recipe several times and it is my favorite cornbread recipe. I now cut the butter milk in half and substitute creme fraich in. I also melt the butter separately and preheat the skillet in the oven till it is frying hot then drop the half portion of butter into the hot skillet followed by the batter. I love cornbread cooked in the cast iron skillet because it adds a little extra browned crunch on the bottom.
I have tried many cornbread recipes. can not stand it when you cut into it and it crumbles. I can cut a piece of this one and walk away. no crumbs dropping as I go.
I love this recipe!

I made it almost exactly as written. Chef John said if you could play with amount of liquid so I did. 1-3/4 cup of buttermilk, and an added tablespoon of white sugar because I had exactly 2-1/2 tablespoons of honey. Delicious.
It's spot on. Easy and holds together well
Great recipe and easy to do.
I made it just as the recipe said, and it turned out great! I feel like it needs a little more flavor, so it was suggested to me to add crumbled bacon! Because, who doesn't love bacon??
I didn't make any changes to the recipe. So simple and easy to make. Will definitely make this again!
Easy to make and tastes great. I added a can of drained Southwestern Style Corn which really gives it a punch and added flavor.
Followed the recipe, turned out very good. Will make this again.
I've tried several different cast iron cornbread recipes. This one is tops!

YES I'll make it again! It is DELICIOUS!! 
Now I gotta stop eating it...there won't be any left for dinner.

I only had "salted" butter so I reduced the salt in the batter to 1/4 teaspoon. Nor did I have honey so I used MAPLE SYRUP instead. I had some SHARP CHEDDAR I needed to use up so I added about 1 cup. 
And it's true, the cayenne didn't make it spicy just added a touch of flavor.

No sugar, no flour.Use baking soda-no baking powder needed.
Let them eat cake!
thank you! i didn;t have cayenne so i used ancho. next time cayenne!
It was very good but my husband would have liked it sweeter

Not so great!

It was an ok texture and consistency but definitely missing something. I would add a can of creamed corn or something else to sweeten it up.

I used powdered buttermilk in place of fresh and added about 4 tablespoons of honey. I also added about 1/2 cups shredded cheddar to the mixture and then topped it in the pan with a handful more of cheese. The texture was just moist enough to not make a mess of crumbs and cooking it in a 10-inch skillet created a nice, chewy crust. May sound awful to some but I loved it.
Great. Did in Corning ware as I don’t have cast iron. Easy and delicious. Great with lots of butter. Served it with Brown Rice and Black Bean Casserole.
Really good, really easy cornbread recipe. Went great with my mom's famous chili recipe.
None !
Yes turned out awesome my husband liked it I used half of olive oil and half butter and spread some sesame on top it was moist and soft too good
This gave me the cornbread I was looking for. Dense, not crumbly. Easy to pick up and eat out of hand.

This is a scrumptious REAL cornbread recipe. It is not the yellow cakey sweet cornbread that some restaurants serve, it is a real, corn-mealy cornbread. It is delicious as is, or with the addition of chopped jalapenos or corn or whatever. The cayenne adds flavor, but not heat. Don't leave it out. Well done, Chef John!
Very easy to make and tastes amazing. I did however, add 2 teaspoons baking power ( I didn’t have self rising flour

This is without question the best cornbread recipe I have ever made! I added 1/2 can of Sweet Corn, a small can of Mild Green Chili’s and 5 slices of Candied Bacon which was chopped up. I used a 12” Cast Iron Skillet and cut the time down to 22 minutes at 400 with the oven set on Convection. Serve it with Honey along side of my homemade Chili. Wow!!
I did not change anything, this is great tasting cornbread.Even my 10yr old loved it. Thank you.
I added canned Jalapenos and Monterey Jack Cheese and Cheddar Cheese and sprinkled some on top before baking . I am from Texas and this is how we always made it . Really scrumptious.
The only thing I would change is the not adding the cayenne pepper. I didn't really like the spiciness. Otherwise, I loved it.....it wasn't dry at all. I will make it again.
Agree with reducing the amount of butter as mentioned in the notes. But an otherwise easy/handy recipe.

I made this! Its not bad instead of buttermilk I had to use evaporated milk and dilute then add 1&1/2 tbsp white wine vinegar to get to buttermilk. Everything else is the same minus the addition of a 1/2 tsp of baking powder because I don't have self rising flour. I'm not sure what the cayenne is playing at but I think the addition of jalapenos chucks may be decent.
Also I next time I am going to add all the dry ingredients together and then add the buttermilk then the eggs whisk and let sit for a bit like 5 minutes then add in that butter mix and pour right back into that cast iron. 
I would make it again because of how easy it is to prepare
Took it to our pot luck at church and got rave reviews.
I did not care for this recipe.

I didn't like it that much. I followed the recipe exactly the 1st time and then a second time with changes. I used a cup and a half of cornmeal and a half cup of the self rising flour the second time. I mixed all the melted butter into the wet ingredients and then mixed this into the dry, poured into the skillet and baked. My changes made it only slightly better. I liked the flavor, but not the texture. I thought my changes would improve the texture. They did, but only slightly. I would definitely try it, different tastes for different folks. I just like other recipes better.
Followed the recipe as C. John outlined. This was delicious and fun to make. 4 instead of 5 starts because the leftovers became hard and inedible. So if you make it, eat it all that first night! :-)
Delicious!!!
It was very easy to make! I am used to a very southern cornbread, not sweet, but I have to say the honey was good and everyone loved it! I'd make it again!
